docs.lead_paragraph: Michigan is one of those states in which neither Democrats nor Republicans consistently stay on the top of the political heap. So it should come as no great surprise that next year's race for the United States Senate is tight. In fact, the race, in which Representative Debbie Stabenow, a moderate-to-liberal Democrat from Lansing, is trying to unseat the conservative Republican incumbent, Spencer Abraham, is shaping up as one of the most competitive congressional contests of Election 2000. And also one of the most expensive.

headline.main: Political Briefing; Santa Takes Sides In Michigan Contest

docs.abstract: Rep Debbi Stabenow, moderate-to-liberal Michigan Democrat, is in a statistical tie with Sen Spencer Abraham, conservative Republican she is trying to unseat; Santa Claus is featured in Democrat ad attacking Spencer's record on health care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A STUDY released last week by Fordham University that measures the social health of Connecticut found that life is improving for the majority of citizens, but becoming increasingly stressful for some young people and the working poor. The report, ''The Social State of Connecticut '99'' and prepared by the university's Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y., studied how Connecticut is faring in 11 social areas and found that the state is performing at its highest level in nine years. The study said the state is providing the most affordable housing and the highest average weekly wages in nearly 30 years. The state also recorded good marks in infant mortality and high school completion.

headline.main: State's Social Health Ranks High, but Not in All Areas

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten of the state's largest health insurers have agreed to cover experimental cancer drug treatments for more than 25,000 patients. Now, only 3 percent of the state's 275,000 cancer victims, or about 8,200, are in clinical trials, which test the effectiveness of drugs. Such treatments are rarely covered by insurance. The coverage is scheduled to begin next year, possibly by spring. The insurance would include drugs, doctor visits, hospitalization, CT-scans and lab fees.

headline.main: Insurers Agree to Cover Cancer Drug Trials

docs.abstract: Ten of New Jersey's largest insurers agree to cover experimental drug treatments for cancer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the six months when her 66-year-old father was dying from cancer, Carolyn Aldige relied completely on doctors at Eastern Virginia Medical Center for information. But, she says, none of them ever mentioned the possibility that he might take part in a clinical trial. ''I didn't even know what the words clinical trial meant,'' said Ms. Aldige, who after that experience in the 1980's went on to found the Cancer Research Foundation of America. ''I was just clueless.''

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Insurers Come in From The Cold on Cancer

docs.abstract: Growing number of insurance companies agree to pay for experimental cancer treatments administered to policyholders who participate in clinical trials sanctioned by federal health agencies; experts call development momentous; for almost two decades, cancer researchers have been fighting over inadequate federal payments for clinical trials; change has come as courts and state legislatures, faced with desperate patients, have begun to require insurers to pay for experimental therapies; photo (M)

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA and KURT EICHENWALD

docs.lead_paragraph: By agreeing Friday on a $1 billion plan to provide health insurance for a third of the state's 3.2 million uninsured, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders sent a message to the rest of the country that New York is trying to regain its stature as a leader on health care policy. At the beginning of the decade, the number of New Yorkers without health insurance was below the national average; now, at the end of the decade, it exceeds it. Roughly 20 percent of New York's residents under 65 do not have insurance; the national average is 16.3 percent.

headline.main: Aid Plan for the Uninsured Carries a National Message

docs.lead_paragraph: With advocates for the disabled gathered around him at the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial, President Clinton signed landmark legislation today that could allow millions of people with disabilities to enter the work force by lifting restrictions on their health care coverage. Advocates consider the legislation the most significant step for the disabled since the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990. The law expands Medicaid and Medicare so that people with disabilities will continue to receive health insurance coverage once they go to work.

headline.main: Clinton Signs Law to Help Workers With Disabilities

docs.lead_paragraph: The 55-cent-a-pack increase in New York State's cigarette tax agreed to today by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders is the latest in a series of heavy blows against the tobacco companies, an industry that just a few years ago seemed invulnerable. The most glaring setback occurred in lawsuit settlements with the states in 1998, for $246 billion over 25 years. But as sentiment against tobacco has grown, there have been numerous other defeats. In the last five years, the federal government and 19 states have increased their tobacco taxes.

headline.main: Tobacco Politics; Industry Grown Vulnerable Is Now A Target of Opportunity for Taxation

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders from both major parties agreed today to raise the state's cigarette tax by 55 cents a pack in an ambitious effort to provide health care coverage for as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers. Mr. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature also decided to renew a program that pays hospitals about $1.3 billion a year to train new doctors and treat poor people who show up in their emergency rooms with no way of paying their bills. The program had been set to expire at the end of the year, threatening the state's health care system with financial uncertainty.

headline.main: NEW YORK RAISING TAX ON CIGARETTES TO HELP UNINSURED

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders from both parties agree to raise state cigarette tax by 55 cents a pack in ambitious effort to provide health care coverage for as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers; also decide to renew program that pays hospitals about $1.3 billion a year to train new doctors and treat poor people who show up in emergency rooms with no way of paying their bills; plan to expand coverage for the uninsured would be financed with revenue from added cigarette tax, state's share of national tobacco settlement and new federal health care funds; charts of cigarette prices and taxes in New York City, New York State and other states (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the joint appearance last night of the two candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription agency. The town hall meeting was held in Nashua, N.H., where members of the audience asked the candidates questions, and its moderator was Ted Koppel of ABC News. MR. BRADLEY -- I think that the issue really is the health care system is in real distress. There are millions of Americans out there today who have health insurance that are afraid they're not going to be able to see a doctor or to get a hospital. There are millions of middle-class Americans that are really on the brink of losing their health insurance. . . .
docs.abstract: Excerpts from transcription of debate between Vice Pres Al Gore and Bill Bradley
docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from the joint appearance last night of the two candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing...

docs.lead_paragraph: Displaying a calm persistence and aggressiveness, former Senator Bill Bradley tried to poke holes tonight in Vice President Al Gore's health care, education and gun control proposals in their second televised encounter. Mr. Gore, in turn, questioned his rival's commitment to education, health care and managing the economy. Nearly two months after the first debate, when he declined to engage Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley tried a strikingly different approach in their 90-minute encounter at Daniel Webster College here, which was televised tonight on the ABC News program ''Nightline.''

headline.main: Bradley, in Debate With Gore, Goes on the Attack

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and former Sen Bill Bradley hold second televised debate, focusing largely on education and health care issues; photos (M)
